results.title: Chinese Diggers
results.creator_credit: Teck Tan, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
A Prizewinner at the 31st International Film and TV Festival of New York this program looks at Australia’s attitude to Chinese Australians who wanted to join the Armed Forces to assist in the defence of Australia during the Second World War. In examining the stories of those interviewed a number of issues are brought to light. The video is accompanied by Teacher’s notes and workcards.

results.title: Chinatown [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Roman Polanski, Robert Evans, Long Road Productions and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Chandleresque private eye J.J. Gittes takes on the seemingly routine investigation of an errant husband but is soon caught up in a network of private and public evil. Drought-stricken Los Angeles in 1937 is a disorienting and alien place. In this multi-layered narrative, marked by dark humour, the mysterious Chinatown, where social and moral norms don’t operate, acts as a metaphor for a pervasive corruption implicating the past, the present and the future. Stars John Huston, Jack Nicholson and Faye Dunaway. Also availble on VHS [302476].

results.title: China: times of silk and gold (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Gill and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Professor William Watson, Professor of Chinese Art and Archaeology at the University of London, and Magnus Magnusson continue their journey across modern China, visiting one of the world’s great Buddhist shrines; the caves at Lyang; Sian, the ancient capital; and the tomb of a T’ang princess who died in 701 AD In the Forbidden City of Kubblah Khan in Peking, a remarkable clock is discovered - a present to the Emperor from Britain’s first trade mission in the 18th century.

results.title: China: times of jade and bronze (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Gill and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: In 1973 an exhibition of Chinese art was presented at the Royal Academy in London. Many of the prize pieces appear in this film, which evolves into an extensive journey through modern China to visit many of the sites from which the treasures came, putting them into the context of place and history. With William Watson and Magnus Magnusson. Museum sequences directed by Ray Sutcliffe, photographed by Phil Meheux.

results.title: China: the middle kingdom
results.creator_credit: Link House Communications and Highlight International Films
results.brief_description: At one time it was considered the centre of civilization, “The Middle Kingdom”. China’s survival is dependent on its one great resource, its people. A look at China from within, its people and customs, its idealism and shortcomings.

results.title: China: the mandate of heaven
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Maryland Public Television and ITV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Legacy”.
China was the last of the great civilisations to develop independently, but it developed a vision of life unique to itself, centred on two quite separate philosophies - moral order, sustained by ritual, as taught by Confucius and the mysticism of Taoism, or the search for the”right way”. Chinese history is permeated by the search for harmony, and a belief in the self-sufficiency and order of Chinese culture, so that outside contact has been viewed as unnecessary and mostly discouraged - even to the present day.

results.title: China: The Long March
results.creator_credit: Peter Butt, Chris Hooke and Independent Productions (AU)
results.brief_description: An Australian photographer takes a historic journey retracing the historic trail of the Long March, by which Mao Tse Tung led 100,000 Communist cadres, on foot, across China. Traversing rivers, forests, mountain ranges and wild steppes, the Long March was central to consolidating the Communist Party’s support from the Chinese peasantry. This video offers an excellent historic account of the history of the Long March, as well as offering a breathtaking visual exploration of China and its people.

results.title: China: Sichuan province
results.creator_credit: Shirley Sun and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: Sichuan Province, located in central China, is the most populous of all China’s Provinces. This film follows the route of the Chang Jiang (Yangtze River) as it flows eastwards from the mountainous Qinghai-Tibet Plateau to the fertile Sichuan Basin. The video looks at rice and wheat cultivation, mealtimes in a rural household, a government station where farmers sell their produce, and a rural school. The video also examines the people, commerce and industry of Chongqing, Sichuan’s largest city.
